author: DAVID DOWNEY
title: WILDFIRES: Fire prevention fund still has $43 million
text:
By DAVID DOWNEY / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 9:19 p.m. WILDFIRES: Fire prevention fund still has $43 million Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Related article » As California was withering from historic drought and entering one of its worst wildfire seasons, the state closed the books on its most recent budget year having left $43 million in fire prevention money in the bank, according to Cal Fire officials.
That disclosure angered an Inland Southern California politician who opposed a fee on rural property owners when adopted in 2011 to raise funds for prevention – defined as activities such as shrub and tree thinning, defensible space inspection, arson investigation and fire-threat mapping.
Riverside County Supervisor Kevin Jeffries, a former lawmaker who twice sought unsuccessfully to repeal the fee, said it is alarming that so much money was unspent.
“You certainly owe it to the taxpayers who are paying this illegal fee to actually give them what they are supposed to get for their tax dollars,” Jeffries said last week.
Daniel Berlant, a spokesman for Cal Fire, the state’s firefighting agency, said in a telephone interview there was $43 million in the fire prevention account when fiscal year 2014-15 wrapped up June 30.
Still, Berlant said many projects have been tackled – and continue to be tackled. He said officials have been cautious in their spending because the fee is new and they weren’t sure how much it would bring in.
‘SAVING A LARGE STASH’ “Given the fact that it’s a relatively new fund, there’s not a long track record on receipts,” said state Department of Finance spokesman H.D. Palmer. “We do want to maintain a prudent reserve for unforeseen circumstances.”
State Sen. Jim Nielsen, R-Gerber, who sits on a budget subcommittee with Cal Fire oversight, rejected the notion that officials were being prudent.
“They’re hoarding it,” Nielsen said. “What for, I don’t know.”
Jeffries thinks he knows. He said it’s likely related to a suit challenging the fee’s legality.
Critics who contend the fee is an illegal tax have gone to court over the matter. And in August, a Sacramento County judge elevated the case to class-action status. A trial is anticipated next year.
Should the state lose, it may have to refund an estimated 12,000 property owners as much as $7 million.
“It seemed pretty clear to me that they were saving a large stash of it in anticipation of this court ruling,” Jeffries said.
Berlant denied that is the case.
“That’s not accurate,” Berlant said. “The courts will make their decision. In the meantime, we’re going to continue our work.”
